A Sci-Fi Thriller Classic. The ideas explored here from Robots, love, humanity and where the moral lines between all of them are drawn are really well done and doesn't really offer many answers to such complex topics. But what it does offer is a pretty satisfying revenge thriller in place of answers. The acting and soundtrack are pretty solid and everything else is really well done. Iris is really good and the best thing acting wise. Everyone else is solid but not as fleshed out especially the supporting characters who blend in a bit. Josh is good but fasinating watching how our feelings towards him turn into a complete 180 the more things go on. the direction is pretty solid, the setting is memorable, and this makes very clever use of 2020's technology in a very clever and witty way. This is half a Sci-fi movie and half revenge movie which works quite well. There are a few suspension of disbelief moments in this like how this has never happened before and no one knows about this. Or how Josh is able to jail break Iris to begin with pretty easily. And how why he doesn't turn her off instantly after the Sergei incident. Also it explores a lot and can be slightly jumpy with so many ideas that it touches in different ways but works quite well. Despite those issues where it asks you to just forget about certain plot holes everything else is so well done and so much is explored that it's so easy to forgive it and become immersed in it. Anyone who is a fan of Sci-Fi, Thrillers, revenge flicks, or any actors in this or the director should give this a try. One of the biggest suprises of the year.

This science fiction thriller follows a couple on a weekend getaway with friends at a remote cabin, which unravels into chaos after a revelation that one of the guests is a subservient android built for human companionship. An excellent concept that is impressively executed, with Sophie Thatcher delivering a standout performance as the emotional anchor of the film. Reminiscent of a Black Mirror episode, the story is full of clever twists and maintains a gripping pace. What sets it apart is its refreshing perspective: instead of portraying AI as a threat, the narrative flips expectations, making the audience empathize with the android’s journey toward freedom. The ending is both bold and satisfying, making this a thoughtful and thrilling ride.

SPOILERS AHEAD: I really enjoyed this film. It was a strong showing overall, and Sophie Thatcher is one of the best up-and-coming actresses working today. Her performance here only reinforces that, and I'm genuinely looking forward to seeing more from her. I'm currently watching Yellowjackets after hearing she was in it, and she’s absolutely a scene-stealer there as well. She brings an intensity and presence that elevates every moment she's on screen. Back to the movie, what stood out most for me was the character arc of Iris. Her transformation, the way she strategically formulates a plan for escape and revenge, and ultimately fights for her own redemption—despite not being human—was both powerful and satisfying. You genuinely root for her, and her eventual peace feels well-earned. One of my favorite moments was when she programmed herself to speak only in German to the police officer. It was a brilliant move by Iris and flawlessly delivered by Sophie Thatcher, who completely nailed that scene. This was a smart, emotionally resonant sci-fi thriller film with a standout performance at its core. Also, good acting by Jack Quaid and Lukas Cage. I’d give it a solid 4 out of 5 stars.

I must admit, having no idea what the movie is about has put me in a position to be constantly surprised. I stayed away from the film’s trailer or any clips so I had no clue about the plot. Surprise, surprise! When Sophie’s character was narrating during the first few seconds of the film, it already introduced an idea to the audience about its nuances: rom-com, gory, thriller. And I thought, this is another suspense thriller movie. The surprise element of the movie came sooner than expected and it’s one of the several things I appreciate in the film. It’s fast paced and unapologetic of being blunt. It’s straightforward right from the start when Sophie Thatcher’s character mentions killing his goofy boyfriend at the onset of the film.  The message of the film may be clear: AI being dangerous to the society, bots making a dark turn and harming humans. However, the film’s vision did not disappoint and generously delivered the action-filled sci-fi storyline that the audience deserved. The narrative benefits from great comedic timing, it got a chuckle out of me at times. This speculative thriller is innovative and clever, with a masterful plot, rapid action, and a sharp sense of wit. All the elements in the film perfectly blend together and create an entertaining story. A cast could also make or break a movie but everyone played the characters well. Sophie Thatcher and Jack Quaid both delivered amazing and consistent performances. Their performances played a key role in elevating the film. Director Drew Hancock has crafted a sophisticated and fresh Sci-Fi film, with Eli Born’s cinematography playing a pivotal role in bringing the vision to life. The film is not perfect, it may have a few minor flaws, but it’s definitely worth overlooking.  I recommend this movie 100%.

Companion is a genre-defying thrill ride—darkly funny, wildly inventive, and relentlessly intense. With standout performances from Sophie Thatcher and Jack Quaid, Drew Hancock delivers a smart, stylish, and unpredictable film that keeps you guessing at every turn. I have to admit, I was completely mistaken about this movie. For a whole month, I kept putting it off, laboring under the assumption that it would simply be another entry in the well-worn genre of AI-gone-wrong films, filled with cold, emotionless robots embarking on destructive rampages. How wrong I was! This film truly stands apart. It distinguishes itself from the multitude of AI movies in several remarkable ways. It's a refreshing and unique take on the subject matter. First and foremost, I must give immense credit to the exceptional performances of Sophie Thatcher and Jack Quaid. They both delivered truly captivating portrayals that grounded the film in a powerful sense of realism and empathy. As an audience, you don't just observe the characters; you genuinely connect with them, investing in their emotional journeys. Their performances draw you in and make the unfolding events feel deeply personal and relatable. The chemistry between them is palpable, further enhancing the film's emotional core. The plot itself feels remarkably plausible and natural, which is a testament to the skillful storytelling. It doesn't rely on outlandish, far-fetched scenarios, but rather explores themes that resonate with our current reality and the trajectory of technological advancement. The narrative unfolds in a way that feels believable, making the film all the more compelling. And let's not forget the masterful direction of Drew Hancock. Hancock's vision and execution are evident in every frame, guiding the film with a steady hand and creating a cohesive and immersive cinematic experience. The pacing is excellent, allowing the story to unfold gradually while maintaining a sense of engagement. The visual language of the film is also noteworthy, contributing to the overall atmosphere and emotional impact. I wholeheartedly recommend this movie. It's an ideal choice for a date night, offering plenty to discuss and reflect on afterward. It's also perfect for a movie night with friends, providing an engaging and thought-provoking experience that I can guarantee you won't regret. This isn't just another AI movie; it's a film that explores the complexities of human-technology relationships with nuance and depth.

We just finished watching Companion (2025) and let’s just say… it was not what we expected—and that’s exactly why we’re still thinking about it. Based on the trailer, we thought we were walking into a futuristic romance—maybe a gentle sci-fi film about a man falling in love with his AI partner. But within the first few minutes, it became clear: this wasn’t soft or sweet. It was creepy, intense, and psychologically disturbing. The trailer totally misleads you, but honestly, that’s part of the brilliance. Plot & Themes Without spoiling too much, the story revolves around Iris (played by Sophie Thatcher), who seems like the perfect girlfriend—until she discovers she was programmed to be that way. The movie quickly shifts into a dark exploration of control, free will, and what it means to be “made” for someone else. It asks: If your love is designed, is it even real? It’s haunting, powerful, and forces you to question modern relationships and technology. Visuals & Style The film has a strong film noir vibe—dark shadows, moody lighting, vintage aesthetics mixed with futuristic tech. It’s stylish and eerie. The music also adds a lot: soft synths that make even the quietest moments feel tense. It reminded us of Ex Machina with a bit of Black Mirror and Gone Girl thrown in. Our Final Thoughts This is not a movie you’ll casually forget. It sticks with you. It’s the kind of film you walk out of, sit in the car, and go “Wait… what did we just watch?” Then you talk about it all the way home. If you’re into psychological thrillers, slow burns, and stories that mess with your head—in a good way—Companion is definitely worth watching. Just be ready for something darker and deeper than the trailer suggests.

There is value in not seeing the marketing for certain movies, and Companion is one of them. But even if the premise is known, the story adds just enough additional twists to keep it interesting. In the 1972 novel, “The Stepford Wives”, the protagonist slowly realizes she will be murdered and replaced by a docile, submissive robot. Its bleak ending suggests that they succeeded with the replacement, and her automaton version greets her human husband at the grocery store. Meanwhile, Companion, paying homage to the novel, introduces Iris as she meets the love of her life for the first time at a grocery store. In a voiceover she exclaims “There were two times I felt truly happy. First, the day I met Josh; second, the day I killed him.” This sets up the story as an antithesis to the novel, because it’s about a woman who discovers that she is herself a robot and proceeds to rebel against her human partner and programming. Sophie Thatcher, playing the companion robot - Iris, has earned herself another film to grace her scream queen portfolio. She does so much with her frantic expressions and sells the desire for self-preservation. Jack Quaid (Josh) on the other hand, can sometimes be indistinguishable from his ‘Hughie’ character from ‘The Boys’ so he sprinkles this performance with sociopathic traits that slowly reveal themselves as the story progresses. Murder-bots, robots unaware they are robots, owners taking advantage of them and robots wanting freedom and autonomy are common tropes of the genre. Companion utilizes this to a degree and adds elements of horror-comedy to keep things fresh. The obvious nods to Terminator: Judgement Day is also a nice touch.

Nachdem der Russe durch einen Unfall stirbt, werden Geheimnisse gelüftet und Iris muss vor Josh und den anderen flüchten. Ist Josh böse oder ist dies nur ein Missverständnis? Der Anfang des Films ist einfach nur schlecht. In den ersten Minuten spoilert uns der Hauptcharakter schon wie der Film enden wird. Dadurch wird keine Spannung aufgebaut, da man ehe weiß, wie es endet. Der Film ist zwar sehr vorhersehbar und man hätte es ehe früh genug gesehen, aber das der Film uns schon ganz am Anfang sagt, wie er endet, lässt jede Hoffnung schwinden. Es wäre interessant gewesen, wäre das Ereignis, welches gespoilert wurde in der Mitte gewesen, das wäre eine gute Überraschung gewesen. Die ersten 15 Minuten waren total langweilig und ich dachte das dieser Film ein langweiliger Film werden würde. Dies war aber nicht der Fall. Es ist zwar nichts Neues, dennoch hat man seinen Spaß damit. Wer den Film M3gan mochte, wird diesen ebenfalls mögen, da dieser eine gewisse Ähnlichkeit mit sich bringt, aber dennoch unterschiedlich ist.

We're in an age where trailers are exceedingly getting worse at revealing spoilers. Studios know it, but do nothing. People know it, yet still watch trailers. You can't only worry about seeing the biggest stunts, or characters who die, or third act reveals, but even first act reveals are easily spoiled. In the case of Companion, its trailer ruins the first act. Even the poster can easily lead you to not have as good as a watch as someone who sees it blindly. It was true joy watching Companion and constantly asking questions about lines of dialogue mean, or why characters are acting the way they do, or where the story is going. Then these questions are answered, and more questions are brought up and then answered. The script cleverly keeps you engaged until the clever end. Like most good movies, the second act takes you on the adventure with a different mindset that you just spent the past twenty minutes in and never lets up with closing any possible holes in the plot, all the while trusting its audience to think outside the movie and see how it relates to the future world that people see coming and know won't work out well. Like many movies, Companion is a warning for humanity. Could what happens in this be a reality one day? The answer is easily, yes. Can it be avoided? Not a chance. Companion will eventually be able to say "told ya so", and it does this by its slick plot that works on a violent twisted level that doesn't have to preach to get its point across. Thankfully the trailer didn't have a voiceover telling the audience what the story is really about.

With symbolism, and special effects, there was a lot to love. The big twist could be taken in a multitude of ways that all speak to the state out the modern world, I adore it. I've never seen such a film with as many sides as a dodecahedron. The concept by itself is already amazing, but with the metaphors of sexual assault, subservience in marriage, involuntary celibacy? Absolutely superb. There's a scene where she rushes to tell her boyfriend that she killed a side character because he wouldn't get off of her, and he says "You couldn't lie to me even if you wanted to." In the context of this movie, it makes sense, but there was something so arrogant about the way he said it, it was vaguely threatening. Like; the detail that our main characters is always dressed in 60s fashion, because that is RIGHT before the women's rights movement, and that character goes on to rebel and kill her male "owner". Symbolism all the way down to the stitching--I'd throw roses if I could, truly. I've never seen the emptiness many women feel when married to someone they may not actually love expressed on screen. Another woman looks at our main lead and says, "You make me feel so...replaceable." That line is so heavy, even put in simple language the line has an impact, another way the movie speaks about the world in less than a minute of it. Even until the end the other main character tries to exert power over her, right up to his death. I look forward to seeing what the director does in the future, as for this--I've been throughly impressed.

The film provides a powerful and incisive analogy about male toxicity, offering a sharp exploration of relationships shapes. Through an engaging narrative, the movie exposes controlling behaviors and the struggle to accept the end of a relationship, highlighting the tendency to shift blame onto the other person as a defense mechanism. The plot is a scathing critique of toxic behavioral patterns, revealing how the inability to handle rejection and take responsibility can perpetuate cycles of manipulation and pain. I highly recommend the film, not only for its cinematic quality but also for its social and psychological relevance, which encourages deep reflection on dysfunctional relational dynamics. O início do ano costuma ser um período complicado para os lançamentos cinematográficos. Tradicionalmente, janeiro e fevereiro são vistos como a "temporada de descarte" de Hollywood, quando estúdios lançam projetos nos quais não depositam grandes expectativas comerciais. Acompanhante Perfeita, novo thriller de comédia produzido pela Warner Bros., tenta driblar esse estigma ao apostar em um conceito contemporâneo e um elenco jovem em ascensão. No entanto, a execução tropeça em decisões criativas questionáveis e na falta de um direcionamento mais preciso, resultando em um filme que entretém, mas não entrega tudo o que promete. Com direção e roteiro de Drew Hancock, que faz sua estreia como cineasta após trabalhar como roteirista em séries como Supernatural e The Flash, o filme parte de uma premissa intrigante: até que ponto a inteligência artificial pode substituir relações humanas? O tema, extremamente atual, tinha potencial para ser explorado de maneira profunda, mas a abordagem escolhida pelo cineasta oscila entre a sátira e o terror leve, sem nunca se comprometer inteiramente com um desses gêneros. A consequência é uma narrativa que parece sempre hesitar, como se tivesse receio de levar sua premissa até as últimas consequências. Se por um lado Hancock apresenta um conceito promissor, por outro, ele se perde ao tentar abordar múltiplos temas sem se aprofundar em nenhum. O longa flerta com discussões sobre a objetificação feminina, a superficialidade das relações contemporâneas e o impacto da tecnologia na sociedade, mas essas reflexões nunca se solidificam completamente, deixando a trama com um tom superficial. Outro ponto que compromete a experiência é a campanha de marketing equivocada. Diferente de Noites Brutais, produção com a qual compartilha alguns membros da equipe e que apostou no mistério absoluto para instigar a curiosidade do público, Acompanhante Perfeita entrega praticamente todo o seu enredo nos materiais promocionais. O trailer revela reviravoltas importantes e enfraquece o impacto do filme para aqueles que já chegam ao cinema cientes de sua proposta. Enquanto o desconhecimento da trama pode proporcionar uma experiência mais envolvente, o excesso de informações divulgadas acaba reduzindo o fator surpresa e prejudicando a imersão de quem esperava algo além do óbvio. Apesar dos problemas, o elenco consegue sustentar parte da narrativa. Jack Quaid, Sophie Thatcher e Lukas Gage formam um trio carismático, e suas performances ajudam a manter o ritmo da história mesmo quando o roteiro se mostra inconsistente. Quaid, em especial, entrega uma atuação que equilibra bem o humor e o suspense, enquanto Thatcher confirma seu talento em ascensão. No entanto, a interação entre os personagens poderia ser mais desenvolvida, já que a curta duração do longa compromete momentos que seriam essenciais para criar conexões mais profundas entre eles. Visualmente, Hancock adota uma direção segura, sem grandes ousadias. Há uma boa utilização de iluminação e cores para criar atmosferas contrastantes entre a frieza da tecnologia e a vulnerabilidade humana, mas nada que realmente se destaque dentro do gênero. A montagem contribui para o tom dinâmico do filme, e algumas sequências de comédia funcionam bem, ainda que a insistência em diálogos expositivos – onde os personagens verbalizam constantemente suas ações e sentimentos – torne a narrativa menos natural. No final, Acompanhante Perfeita funciona dentro da proposta de entretenimento leve, mas deixa a sensação de que poderia ter sido muito mais. Se tivesse abraçado com mais convicção a sátira ou investido em um suspense mais afiado, poderia se destacar dentro do gênero. No entanto, ao tentar equilibrar elementos cômicos e reflexivos sem aprofundá-los, o filme se torna uma experiência divertida, mas facilmente esquecível. Ainda que não seja um desastre, sua execução irregular e a falta de impacto emocional fazem com que, no fim das contas, ele seja apenas mais um lançamento genérico na vasta lista de produções que exploram a relação entre humanos e tecnologia.

Companion is a thrilling sci-fi horror film with a well-conceived plot that feels eerily plausible, painting a future that seems just within reach. The story is gripping, balancing smart comedic moments with serious and intense sequences, making for an engaging experience. Jack Quaid delivers an outstanding performance, proving once again why he's one of the most compelling actors of his generation. His ability to switch between humor and intensity, much like in The Boys, adds depth to the film and makes his character stand out. The film’s twists keep the audience guessing, and while some moments are expected, others hit with surprising force. That said, Companion does have a few shortcomings. The runtime feels a bit too short, leaving some questions unanswered. A little more backstory on the characters—how they knew each other and why they were doing what they were doing—would have added to the emotional investment. While the film does an excellent job at building tension, it could have benefited from expanding its world a little more. Overall, Companion is a captivating and fun watch, delivering a mix of sci-fi horror and dark comedy that keeps viewers entertained. Despite its brevity and lack of deeper exposition, it’s a solid film with strong performances and a well-thought-out premise. Definitely worth watching, especially for fans of Jack Quaid and smartly crafted genre films.

Companion (2025) is another entry in the ever-growing “AI gone wrong” genre, but it does try to shake things up a little. The story is decent, keeping things interesting without dragging too much, though it still hits a lot of familiar beats. The twist on how the AI becomes a problem is a nice touch, but in the end, it doesn’t change the usual outcome. The climax is predictable, but it fits the film, so it doesn’t feel out of place. Visually, the movie looks great. The locations are stunning, and the cinematography really helps set the mood. The directing keeps things moving at a good pace without overcomplicating anything. Sophie Thatcher is easily the standout here, she gives a great performance and makes her character feel real. The rest of the cast is fine, but she’s the one who really carries the film. The script is simple but works for what the movie is trying to do. Some of the dialogue could have been sharper, but nothing feels awkward or forced. The music choice is solid, adding to the atmosphere without being too much. Overall, Companion is a fun watch if you like AI thrillers, but it doesn’t bring anything wildly new to the table. If you liked M3GAN, you’ll probably enjoy this too.

COMPANION Companion is a science fiction horror thriller film starring Sophie Thatcher and Jack Quaid. It's about a couple on a weekend getaway with friends in a remote cabin. It starts out with a romantic vibe, until it turns chaotic after it is revealed that one of the guests is a companion (love doll) robot. It all goes downhill from there. Aside from being charismatic onscreen, Sophie Thatcher has the makings of great actress. Her portrayal of different emotions with her role in this movie is amazing. Jack Quaid also exuded the same versatility with his role as well. Both of their characters shifted from lovingly affectionate to viciously cunning. Companion has similarities with other movies in the same subgenre of killer robots like M3gan. But Companion showed a refreshing different take on it by injecting romance and a little bit of comedy. Overall, it's an interesting romantic, science fiction/horror thriller that's powered by brilliant performances by the charming leads. I hope it gets a sequel. My Rating: ★ ★ ★ ★

A sci-fi thriller with multiple twists and turns, Companion would be most thoroughly enjoyed by those who go in blind. Even having seen the trailer first, this film managed to shock me a number of times. Smart, gory, satirical, and poignant, Companion leaves you thinking of it long after its short (but perfectly timed) hour-and-a-half runtime concludes. The performances by Sophie Thatcher and Lukas Gage are stand-outs. As a viewer, I was able to easily suspend my disbelief, as director Drew Hancock drops us right into the world in which this story takes place. We learn the truths of this world in tandem with our leading lady (or ladybot) Iris, discovering new information as she does along the way. The film takes off a mere 20 minutes in and refuses to ease up on the gas right until the very end. Companion is a reflection of our times, of the state of technology and of bodily autonomy and control in 2025. A must-watch for all fans of horror, sci-fi/fantasy, thrillers, and satire.

Cute. A little weak on story. The details all fell into place rather simply and stupidly. The robot was able to survive and upgrade and escape because the players involved were idiots and the robot was the only person in the entire film with an IQ higher than a clock radio. Felt, cheap? Still, the acting (within the confines of the weak screenplay and script) was decent, the scenes had their moments. The only real gripe was that there was just a little to much robotic convenience, and that it was so stupidly easy to be smart enough hack robots to murder for you, and yet be stupid enough to not know where their HD was or have anything resembling a failsafe? That in the end a robot could be made self controlling with a button press, as if it had never once been tried in a decade or more of these being available? And nobody had ever used a robot to be a bodygaurd or commit a bank robbery, it was just all very, unexplained and unbelievable.

Thank goodness I avoided watching the main trailer or any other promos for Companion. I only saw the teaser, which seemed pretty interesting, and I was intrigued by the marketing, especially the line “From the creators of Barbarian.” Naturally, I assumed it was the same director. I intentionally stayed away from other trailers because I wanted to go in blind. The teaser was very vague, and I wanted to keep that mystery intact. I also didn't read any reviews, as I was really hoping to watch it in theaters, which would’ve been my first theatrical experience of 2025. Unfortunately, I couldn’t make it due to other commitments, but I finally got the chance to stream it. A lot of critics pointed out that the main poster gave away the big twist, but I didn’t feel that way at first. Maybe my vision’s not great, but when I looked at the poster, I thought she was just rolling her eyes upward and to the side—nothing too telling. However, just before I was about to watch the film, I came across a bit of text online that spoiled the twist for me. Suddenly, the poster made sense, and I was kind of bummed. On top of that, I found out the director is a newcomer—not the same one behind Barbarian—which felt a little misleading given the marketing. Still, I was curious and dove into the film anyway. Now, onto the review. Sophie Thatcher is really making a name for herself as a rising star in horror (though I hate the term scream queen). After her standout performance in Heretic last year, she gives another solid performance here in Companion—probably her best yet, though it's not as subtle as what she did in Heretic. She plays Iris, a robot (or, as her boyfriend Josh, played by Jack Quaid, calls her, a "f*ck bot"). Speaking of Quaid, he really impressed me with his darker performance—totally different from his role in The Boys. The supporting cast also did a good job, even though I didn’t recognize many of the actors. What really surprised me about this movie was how much comedy there was. It had a lot more humor than I expected, and I found myself laughing quite a bit. The premise delves into the complexities of AI in physical form and what kind of relationships we could form with them—and vice versa. I totally get that this concept might be unsettling to some, and that’s understandable. With AI evolving so rapidly, though, this kind of reality might not be too far off. The humor was on point, the kills were creative, the acting was strong, and technically, everything worked well. The movie explained the tech in a way that felt sensible within the context. That said, there was one particular kill that felt a bit too far-fetched for my taste. Still, I had a lot of fun with this one. If you’re in the mood for a 90-minute, chamber-piece thriller with a touch of dark comedy, this is definitely worth checking out.

This is the must see movie for me so far this year. Really don't have anything bad to say about it. I loved the cast, specifically Jack Quaid, Sophie Thatcher and Lukas Gage, but everyone is great. The first act does a great job of setting everything up, both the relationship between Quaid and Thatcher, and the chemistry amongst the group once they get to the cabin. When things take off, they take off and it doesn't let up until the credits roll. I loved all the misdirects, the perfectly timed humor, and most importantly, the relationship dynamics at play here. Such a thrilling movie that hits on some great societal topics.

Companion was a great movie, but as the plot unfolded, I found Jack Quaid’s character somewhat unconvincing, which left me questioning certain aspects of the story. My first thought was, Is he serious? Spoiler Alert! If you feel the need to control women—or anyone, for that matter—you’re already a weirdo. But that’s exactly what makes this movie so compelling. It highlights the unsettling reality that some people genuinely desire complete control over others. I think the director did a great job weaving this theme into the film as an underlying message. My rating: 3/5. Definitely worth a watch for the thought-provoking premise.

It was good but it was missing an ingredient. Can't really put my finger on it. It had a dash of this, a dash of that, a slice of this and a cup of that and all stirred together... while it should have been tasty it was a bit hollow. Did it want to be a sci-fi flick? A slasher? Maybe a romance? It should have picked a lane and gone full throttle but instead it stayed in the middle of road. The biggest issue I can point to is the villain, seeing there were instances towards the end where the neon "WHY DOES HE NOT JUST DO THIS?" elephant in room is so loud and clear while the entire climax hinges on the issue all 007 movie villains have. That aspect is a prime example of this movie... it could've recognized what it was doing, grasped it, lifted it up and made it shine but it didn't and decided mid-road was the best approach.
